node.text:
As New Yorkers commemorate the 20th anniversary of 9/11, they are also contemplating how to recover from covid-19.

After the attacks of 2001, New York came back stronger—so what lessons can its leaders learn from that success to help the city bounce back today?

Cover image credit: Gary Hershorn/Getty Images

node.title: From 9/11 to covid-19: can New York recover?

node.text:
The pandemic not only disrupted education—it also thrust technology onto a sector which historically has been slow to adopt it. Will classrooms ever be the same again?

Cover image credit: Ben Hasty/MediaNews Group/Reading Eagle via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: how tech will transform your kids’ education

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.text: The race between covid-19 vaccines and variants is on. Alok Jha, The Economist’s science correspondent, and Natasha Loder, our health policy editor, discuss what this means for the future. Cover image credit: Alamy

node.title: Covid-19: can vaccines keep up with variants?

node.text: The Taliban’s swift return to power in Afghanistan has shocked the world and humiliated America. What effect will this have on the international standing of the US and on global security? Our experts answer your questions. Cover credit: AP

node.title: Afghanistan: how the Taliban weakened America

node.text:
Most governments recognise that vaccination is the fastest way out of the pandemic, but in many places hesitancy is hindering the roll-out. Should employers—or even governments—force people to have the vaccine? We answer your questions.

Cover image credit:

node.text:
The covid-19 pandemic has reinforced humanity’s dependence on modern tech, but the same tools that enable remote working are also being used to spread disinformation and perpetuate cybercrime. Ambivalence towards technology is nothing new.

Cover image credit: Scott Strazzante/The San Francisco Chronicle via Getty Images

node.text:
In the past couple of weeks South Africa has witnessed the worst violence since the end of apartheid in 1994. Our correspondent in Johannesburg explains what he has seen on the streets and why the country is in crisis. 

Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: South Africa: what's behind the riots?

node.text:
In America, the intelligence services deem far-right extremism a greater domestic threat than Islamist terrorism. The pandemic has exacerbated the spread of white supremacism and neo-Nazism.

Cover image credit: Michael Nigro/Pacific Press/LightRocket via Getty Images

node.title: Fortnite to far right: the rise of digital extremism

node.text:
Across much of the world, covid-19 restrictions are starting to ease. The Economist has crunched the data to calculate how close countries are to pre-pandemic levels of normality—but will life ever be the same again? 

Click on the link in our bio to visit our website and explore our interactive normalcy tracker. It covers 50 countries which account for 76% of the world’s population and 90% of its GDP.

Cover image credit: Lluis Gene/AFP via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: why your life will never be the same again

node.text:
The world’s animals and wildlife are going extinct at a greater rate than at any time in human history. Can technology help turn the tide?

Cover image credit: Yashpal Rathore/Nature Picture Library

node.title: Mass extinction: what can stop it?

node.text: The number of working-age people in China is shrinking. Could this threaten the country’s rise as an economic superpower? Credit: Eyevine

node.title: China’s economy: what’s its weak spot?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in Sandakan.

node.text:
If you’ve had to do a covid test before, this orangutan’s expression probably looks familiar.⁠
⁠
It is pictured here getting tested for the virus at the Sepilok Orangutan Rehabilitation Centre in Sandakan, Malaysia.⁠
⁠
Luckily for this ape, the result was negative. ⁠
⁠
If you’re interested in taking a closer look at the science news shaping our world, you might like our free Simply Science newsletter, delivered weekly.⁠
⁠
To sign up, tap on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Credit : AFP

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in Washington D.C.. May be an image of text.

node.text:
Unlike most rich European countries, America lacks a coherent public child-care regime.⁠
⁠
In 1971 it came surprisingly close to having one when Congress passed a comprehensive child-care plan. But President Richard Nixon vetoed it, calling it “the most radical piece of legislation” to have crossed his desk.⁠
⁠
Now Democrats are trying again, fashioning a child-care system as part of an enormous social-spending package. ⁠
⁠
The potential gains from more systematic support are large. But there are trade-offs around its design, too, says our Free exchange columnist. To read why the search is still on for a truly effective American nanny state, click on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @ottographic

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 16, 2021. May be an image of outdoors and text that says 'Science & technology The world's biggest carbon-removal plant switches on'.

node.text:
Will technology be able to reverse some aspects of climate change? One Icelandic company is pulling carbon out of the air.⁠
⁠
The Orca carbon-capture plant will catch 4,000 tonnes of carbon dioxide a year, out of around 35bn tonnes produced by burning fossil fuels. ⁠
⁠
It will cost somewhere between $600-800 to sequester one tonne of carbon dioxide, and the firm sells offset packages online for around $1,200 per tonne. ⁠
⁠
With limited capacity and a high price point, there is still a lot of work to be done for this type of operation to make a real dent in emissions.⁠
⁠
Despite these concerns, customers are lining up. Tap on the link in our bio to read more about how carbon removal is starting to make waves.⁠
⁠
Credit: Climeworks

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 16, 2021. May be an image of sky and text that says 'Leaders Supply chains are adapting, not failing মम্ EVERGREEN EVERGREEN 22221 6462147'.

node.text:
Remember Ever Given? ⁠
⁠
The global supply chain has faced a series of disruptions over the past few months.⁠
⁠
But amid logistics blues, markets are working as they tend to do, and firms are finding routes around blockages.⁠
⁠
Under intense pressure, global supply chains are not in fact failing; they are, rather, adapting. ⁠
⁠
Skippers aren't scuppered. To read why global supply chains will survive this trial, tap on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Credit: Press Association

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in New York, New York. May be an image of text that says 'In America, even full local hospitals do not dent vaccine scepticism Adults who are uncertain or unwilling to get vaccinated against covid-19, 2021, % Russia Japan 60 50 Australia 40 United States China 30 Global average 20 Apr May 10 Jun Source: Morning Consult Jul Aug The Economist'.

node.text:
A glance at this chart of global vaccine scepticism shows an alarming trend for Americans. ⁠
⁠
While other rich countries see a steadily downward slope, America is flatlining. ⁠
⁠
The highly contagious Delta variant continues its march across the country, wreaking havoc on the South, one of the country’s least-vaccinated regions. ⁠
⁠
Deaths have risen to levels not seen since March, before the vaccine was widely available: numbers that recall the early months of the pandemic. ⁠
⁠
As many Americans have scrambled for futile cures like ivermectin, an anti-parasitic drug, interest in the most effective solution—the vaccine—is stuck. To read why full hospital wards are having little effect on vaccine take-up, click on the link in our bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 16, 2021.

node.text:
Need some space?⁠⁠
⁠⁠
These award-winning photographs are a selection from this year’s @royalmuseumsgreenwich Astronomy Photographer of the Year competition. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Swipe left to see the overall winning entry. “The Golden Ring”, by Shuchang Dong, captures the annular solar eclipse that occurred on June 21st 2020. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Other winners include a smiley face in space, captured by Nicolas Rolland and Martin Pugh, and a family portrait of the solar system, taken by 15-year-old Zhipu Wang. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Which is your favourite? Let us know below. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
And if these photos have left you curious for more stories about life beyond Earth, tap on the link in our bio to read about the growing business of tracking space debris. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Image credits for #APY13: ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
1) Bogdan Borz, ”Clouds in IC“⁠⁠
2) Shuchang Dong, ”The Golden Ring“⁠⁠
3) Jin Yang, ”Van Gogh’s Sketchpad“⁠⁠
4) Nicolas Rolland and Martin Pugh, ”A Smiley in Space“⁠⁠
5) 至璞 王 (Zhipu Wang), ”Family Photo of the Solar System“⁠⁠
6) Frank Kuszaj, ”A Colourful Quadrantid Meteor“

Clear thinking about child labour SEPTEMBER18TH-24TH202 Down the rabbit hole The promise and perils of decentralised finance'.

node.text:
Decentralised finance is one of three tech trends disrupting the industry, along with tech platforms and digital government currencies (or “govcoins”).⁠
⁠
But “DeFi”, as it is known, aims to spread power, not concentrate it. ⁠
⁠
The wave of innovation in decentralised finance is akin to the frenzy of invention in the early phase of the web.⁠
⁠
It has the potential to rewire how the entire system works, with all the promise and perils that entails. ⁠
⁠
DeFi relies upon Ethereum, a blockchain network whose developers view finance as a juicy target.⁠
⁠
Nevertheless, the rise of this ecosystem of financial services deserves sober consideration.⁠
⁠
In our cover this week, we go down the “DeFi” rabbit hole. Click on the link in our bio to learn all about it.⁠
⁠
Credit: Justin Metz/Alamy

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 16, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Covid-19 jabs in America State pressure has a role in public health. Vaccines are no exception The row over vaccine mandates'.

node.text:
By our estimates, the pandemic has claimed 860,000 lives in America. Yet measures to curb the virus by mandating vaccination are being treated as a terrifying affront to liberty.⁠
⁠
With so much risk from the delta variant, your choice over vaccination is everyone’s business. ⁠
⁠
Mandates remain controversial, and many senior Republicans are staunchly opposed. ⁠
⁠
However, the one thing elected officials should not do is to reinforce vaccine hesitancy by falsely presenting all mandates as an attack on constitutional liberties. ⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to read why it is a fatal mistake to treat jabs in this way.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in Sydney, Australia. May be an image of outdoors and text that says 'Asia Australia is getting nuclear submarines, with help from America and Britain'.

node.text:
⁠The new AUKUS alliance reflects a shared concern over China’s growing power.⁠
⁠
The partnership between America, Britain and Australia is based on an Australian idea and will cover diplomatic, security and defence co-operation in the Indo-Pacific.⁠
⁠
Its first initiative, and the jewel in its crown, will be collaboration on future nuclear-powered submarines for the Royal Australian Navy.⁠
⁠
The pact also reflects America’s eagerness to beef up the military capabilities of its Asian partners, and will be signed formally in Washington next week. ⁠
⁠
But nuclear co-operation between the three countries is not without its problems. To learn why, click on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Credit: Peter Parks/AFP via Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 16, 2021. May be an image of sky and text that says 'News SpaceX sends the first-ever civilian crew into Earth orbit'.

node.text:
If you know where to look, the progress of SpaceX’s #Inspiration4 mission will be visible in clear night skies around the world.⁠
⁠
Unlike the trips of Richard Branson and Jeff Bezos, the rocket has gone all the way to orbit. ⁠
⁠
And on Sunday, after more than 40 orbits, the crew of four civilian astronauts will re-enter the atmosphere.. ⁠
⁠
This latest billionaire space mission is the most ambitious yet—and is being chronicled in a Netflix documentary series. ⁠
⁠
Would you like to take a trip into orbit? To learn what the flight means for the future of space travel, tap on the link in our bio. ⁠
⁠
Credit: Florida Today via AP

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 15, 2021. May be an image of 1 person.

node.text:
Versions of layered, nutty pastries may have been made as early as the eighth century BC by the Assyrians, but it was the Ottomans who perfected the sticky glory of baklava.⁠
⁠
Even without the sultans and their acolytes, baklava still evokes a sense of ceremony. Feast days, religious or otherwise, to celebrate both the living and the dead, are occasions for the sweet.⁠
⁠
So, too, are visits by friends. The food writer Claudia Roden, from an Egyptian-Jewish family, said that baklava brings “feelings of well-being, warmth and welcome, of giving and receiving, of crowds of people smiling, kissing, hugging and showering hospitality”.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to read about baklava's multilayered history.⁠
⁠
Illustration: Albane Simon

node.text:
India’s caste system remains entrenched, 75 years after independence. ⁠
⁠
The evil of India’s caste practice is almost as old as the gods, and is the most noxious and evolved example today of how humans attempt to impose superiority and suffering on others by virtue of their birth.⁠
⁠
On top are the Brahmins or priestly caste and at the bottom are the Shudras or labouring castes. The rest do not even count: outcastes.⁠
⁠
In the 1980s  a commission of inquiry deemed 52% of Indians to be members of a new category, “other backward classes”, eligible for reserved public jobs.⁠
⁠
Despite the Supreme Court ruling of no more than 50% of public jobs can be reserved, states regularly breach the limit. Click the link in our bio to read the consequences of affirmative action for the majority.⁠
⁠
